results.title: A Voyage round my father
results.brief_description: A successful barrister and keen amateur gardener, the headstrong and totally perverse Clifford Mortimer banged his head while climbing a tree and was blinded for life. For the next twenty years he refused to admit that anything had changed. His family had to pretend there was nothing wrong and life had to go on as normal. However, life became increasingly complicated and absurd. This is John Mortimer’s warm, witty portrait of his father and his family - filmed in the places where the events actually occurred. The scintillating dialogue and Laurence Olivier’s intensely accurate performance, brilliantly tease out the contradictions in this selfish, heroic man. Also stars Alan Bates and Jane Asher.

results.title: A Vous la France! Eps. 9-15
results.brief_description: The second part of an introduction to simple everyday French designed for anyone who wants to use French on holiday, on business or amongst friends. The course is based on recordings of French people going about their daily lives in shops, at work and at home. The first part of each program introduces basic language to be learnt and the second part is a mini-documentary on aspects of French life as filmed in and around Grenoble and Pezenas in the Languedoc. Workbooks and audio-cassettes are available to reinforce the video programs. Presenters are Carolle Rousseau and Patrick Simpson-Jones.

The course is based on recordings of French people going about their daily lives in shops, at work and at home. The first part of each 25 minute program introduces basic language and the second part is a mini-documentary on aspects of French life as filmed in and around Grenoble. Workbooks and audio-cassettes are available to reinforce the video programs. Presenters are Carolle Rousseau and Patrick Simpson-Jones.

results.title: A Vous la France! [text]
results.creator_credit: British Broadcasting Corporation and Brian Page
results.brief_description: Book to accompany videos. The course is an introduction to simple everyday French. The book contains the texts of all the conversations and interviews together with language notes, background information, quizzes, exercises and a handy reference section. It can be used on its own or in conjunction with the videos. Audio cassettes are also available.

results.title: A Vous la France! [kit]
results.brief_description: Two audio cassettes, Notes for teachers and a workbook to accompany the videorecorded course in French, A vous la France! Together they provide more structured reinforcement of the vocabulary introduced in the programs. The script of the programs is presented in the workbook with exercises and the Teacher’s notes give suggestions as to how best use the materials. The audio-cassettes give examples of correct pronunciation with opportunity to practise at intervals.

results.title: A vous de jouer, Monsieur Vidocq = Your turn Mr. Vidocq
results.brief_description:
Vidocq has an appointment with an old friend from Toulon. But by the time he arrives, his old friend is dead and the police holds Vidocq as the prime suspect.

Credits: Producer, Etienne Laroche ; director, Claude Loursais ; writer, Georges Neveux ; photography, Maurice Damien ; music, Serge Gainsbourg.
Cast: Bernard Noel, Alain Mottet, Genevieve Fontanel, Louis Arbessier, Marguerite Cassan, Claude Cerval.

results.title: A Voice to be heard
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Anthony Buckley and Greg Reading
results.brief_description: In 1973 the National Aboriginal Consultative Committee (N.A.C.C.) was elected for the purpose of giving Aborigines a direct voice in the government. This was the first Australia-wide, elected and representative body of Aborigines in Australia’s history. This film, narrated by the Aboriginal poet Kath Walker, tells the story of the election up to the declaration of the poll and the first meeting of the N.A.C.C. Also takes a searching look at Aborigines as some of the candidates for election speak about their problems.

results.title: A Voice in the city
results.creator_credit: Parker Film Associates and Morten Parker
results.brief_description: Describes the routine daily activities of a union representative member of a District Council in New York City, who looks after the interests of a number of legal municipal unions. Throughout a typically busy week, she mediates on behalf of one local union, settles the grievance of another and recruits members for a new maintenance workers union. Illustrates the important role of the labour union in a democratic society and the many satisfaction’s it offers those who work within it.

results.title: A Voice for the wilderness
results.creator_credit: Yowie Films, Chris Wilcox and Michael Balson
results.brief_description: An examination of rainforests and remaining wilderness areas focusing on the untouched forests (the Antarctic beech forests of the Upper Hastings River Valley of New South Wales) to show the importance of the conservation movement in preserving our wilderness areas. Studies the attitudes to land use from Aboriginal occupancy through the struggle of white settlers and the golden age of timber to the present day when conservation has become a powerful voice world-wide. Outlines the benefits of a rainforest ecology to man and the effects of the depletion of rainforests on the rest of the ecosystem. Examines the relationship of mill workers to their jobs. Uses archival footage and the words of Henry Thoreau from his book “Walden”. Narrated by John Downes.

results.title: A visit with Anne Rice [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Corbitt Design Inc, Pat Corbitt, Anne Rice and Pat Corbett
results.brief_description: Best-selling author of “The Vampire Chronicles”, Anne Rice, discusses subjects that have had a profound affect on her both as an individual and a writer. She focuses mainly on her home town of New Orleans, and covers such diverse but related areas of interest including the people of New Orleans, churches, Catholicism, houses and architecture, religious art, festivals, and death. Includes still images of properties and locations used in some of her novels.
